data.title: Unique Gourmet Dining Experience – Reminds Me of a Fellowship Dinner.
data.text: One of the students told me I should try The Pickle and the Pig. I’m glad I did – it is a unique gourmet dining concept located Downtown in the Legacy Event Center. This quaint and charming sandwich parlor is a partnership with the YWCA. They feature sandwiches made with homemade breads and hand carved deli meats. But also have daily specials, soups, specialty salads and rich desserts! The menu changes daily, so check out their Facebook page to see what specials they are offering before you go. Because the building is used for other special events, the lunch space is set up with long community tables, which remind me of a fellowship dinner at church. Be sure and try the Lobster Bisque. I also had the Mexican Calzone filled with green chile pulled pork, roasted corn, and cheese. It can be hard to find them – look for the small sign near the middle on the South side of the Legacy Center on 14th St.

data.title: Will be back soon!
data.text: The only thing wrong with this place is that it needs more prominent signage outside. I had heard about this great venue inside the Legacy, but circled the building before I finally figured out where to park and enter. You sit at long community tables, which adds to the uniqueness. Soups, salads and sandwiches at lunch were so tempting. I finally settled on the Lobster Bisque and the Paisley Pig Salad. A friend in my group shared the Green Chili Mac and Cheese. Everyone in our party raved on their selections. Still, we missed the famous coconut cake. Dinner is an entirely different menu so I will have to return soon. It's a "must do" in Lubbock's downtown are.

data.title: Two girls doing amazing things in an unusual place
data.text:
Friends have been telling me about the Pickle and the Pig for months now. Recently celebrating their 1st anniversary, the P&P has turned from sandwiches and lunch menu only to dinner menu and they are killing it. 

Both from culinary backgrounds, the girls are working out of the YWCA at the Legacy Events Center at 14th and N. Banquet seating (for now) means you may get to meet some new friends. 

Top notch food and the most polite service I have had in a long time. Coconut fried cod, South African style curry (coconut milk based), Duck Empenadas and many more great treats. Huge portions to boot.

Dessert was a house specialty coconut cake with a pungent lemon citrus kick. We took home more than one.

They are BYOB and at Happy Hour there is no corkage or mixer charge.

data.title: Interesting venue and great food.
data.text: I haven't quite figured this place out.  It is set in the Legacy entertainment building and is a large room with long tables.  If you can get over eating at long tables with complete strangers, the food is delicious.  We came for lunch and fortunately there were so many of us, we had own own table.  The food is fresh and well made.  There is a little art gallery attached so if you have the time, it's a nice visit.  The place doesn't serve liquor, but you can bring your own (wine and spirits.)  The wait staff are nice young men who are attentive and competent.  A pleasant experience.

data.title: Good Food!
data.text: Nice lunch. Long tables, but no problem, can still have great conversation across the table with a friend. Had "Calli-Melt." Really tasty turkey and guacamole (not on menu, but a special and can ask for it) with some spicy for a bit of a kick. Amazing bread for the sandwich. Delicious coconut cake which was split between 2 people. We ate it all! Enjoyed the lobster bisque, really rich...BUT it really needed some more lobster in it. Good beginning service, but later kinda disappeared and had to wait for to-go box and dessert. All in all, a nice lunch place that I'll try again.

data.title: Don't Be in a Hurry
data.text: The Pickle and the Pig is very different from any other restaurant in town.  Located inside the Legacy Event Center on 14th Street.  The menu is full of specialty sandwiches, salads, and soups with combinations of wonderful unusual ingredients put together.  Daily special looked really good and filling.  Plan to sit elbow-to-elbow with strangers, be ready to sit forward so you can hear your lunch partner's conversation and vice-versa, and be prepared for the awkward of feeling like you are intruding on someone else's personal space.  The first time we ate there, we were not seated right next to anyone, but this time, we were seated next to a couple of gentlemen (my girlfriend and I) and then a couple were seated next to us.  It felt crowded and awkward - not a fan!  They have 3 long tables seating 14-18 people, 1 round table of 6 and another 6 foot table for 6 people.  The service is always slow and sporadic.  The servers are very nice, but not really focused on the customers, making service SLOW and not exactly accurate, but not wanting to wait another 20 minutes or more for another sandwich, I scraped off what I didn't like...  Most diners had to flag down their server for boxes or tickets so they could go.  It may be a while before I return.

data.title: Interesting and unique, yet tasty.
data.text:
I was totally not expecting this. Greeted by the very friendly hostess and seated promptly. 

Seating is different- family style; think of a wedding reception and sitting with folks you don't know. You can get over it, as long as you're ok with your dining neighbors peering at what you ordered.

Service was fantastic! Very friendly and courteous. Our waiter(s) all checked on us and filled water as needed.

Food was good! I ordered the Cowboy Cuban and my friend ordered the Culture Club. Cowboy Cuban was very delicious; the jalapeño cheese bread was soft and paired well with BBQ sauce, meat and pickles. I think my friend enjoyed the Culture Club because there was none left.
I also ordered the bisque. Not a huge fan because of the amount flour that was not whisked thoroughly; essential in culinary practices to never have your customers taste flour in their soup. Cream based bisques should always be whisked properly to ensure a smooth, creamy texture. Lots of green onion- maybe use as a garnish or call it a green onion bisque, since I only got a bite or two of imitation lobster meat. I would increase the  amount of brandy/sherry to give it a drunken and/or bisque appeal. It was more like a bowl of white gravy. This is taught in Fundamentals in culinary school as one of the mother sauces/soups. If you really wanna make your mark, I would seriously think about adjusting the bisque.

The price is on point! 

I would absolutely eat here again and recommend folks to try it out!

data.title: Poor service
data.text:
Went in and was immediately seated, order taken within minutes.  Two people- ordered a salad and sandwich. 
Several wait staff would come- "Your order will be in a few minutes "  After 45 min of waiting  we were told our was was messed up and will be out momentarily, waitperon messed it up. This was the third person to placate the long wait  and finally explaining the delay.  
Offered us free desert as a 'peace offering'. 
Had to get up and leave.

data.title: Oustanding Food and Amazing Service
data.text: WOW! What a unique and awesome place. The staff is super friendly and it is a community like atmosphere. The food is phenomenal. You can beat the portion sizes and unique flavors. Can't wait to go back!! GREAT NAME!!!

data.title: Best sandwich in town
data.text: Me and my co-worker come here every few months.  Every sandwich we've tried has been amazing.  The green chili Mac and cheese is a great side dish.

data.title: Hope we were just there on an "off" day
data.text: We went for lunch on a Friday - had to wait a few minutes for a table but had to wait well over an hour to get our food once we ordered and then they were out of what my husband ordered but didn't tell us that until we had sat there an hour waiting.  They appeared very understaffed.  Even once we were told they were out of the meatloaf sandwich we were not given a menu to choose something else - we were told that the chicken salad would be the quickest thing to get since we had already been there that long.  Well apparently, my husband got the last spoonful of chicken salad as that was the quantity on the sandwich.  I did get the sandwich I ordered but not the soup - had to remind the waitress twice about the soup.  Our drinks were never refilled in the one and a half hours we were there.  The family next to us said they were there two hours.  Obviously for a weekday lunch place most people cannot spend over an hour there given most working people only have an hour for lunch.  Also, with such a limited menu it seems you should be able to figure out when you are running low on an item and definitely when you run out so that people don't sit there waiting an hour for a sandwich they are never going to get.  Finally, the banquet style table seating is awful - sitting in such close proximity with strangers does not make for a pleasant dining experience.  Four top tables would be much more pleasant and accommodating for the patrons. The waitress did comp most of our meal but that doesn't change the fact the experience was awful and that my husband ended up having to eat ramen noodles for lunch when we got home!

data.title: Lunch
data.text: Delicious n unique. Spinach bread moist.  Healthy entrees and friendly staff. Repeat lunches and must!!!!

data.title: Great Sandwiches!
data.text:
I stopped in for lunch a couple weeks ago and I am glad I did! The dining area is comprised of 3 long tables that guests share.  We were initially seated on the end by ourselves, but once it started getting busy, we ended up with some strangers right next to us. Not a big deal, but just an observation that you may not have much privacy if that's what you're looking for.  They did have a few separate round tables on the other side of the room though so I'm sure you could request one of those if you had a small group that wanted to sit together. The room had an artsy feel and the wait staff was very professional and polite.

The food was excellent!  That is really what you come for and they surely don't let you down.  I had the Cowboy Cuban. It is jalepeno cheese bread with a spicier version of the traditional cuban sandwich.  I'm a big fan of the origianl cuban and this version was so much better!  All the flavors were a perfect mix so I'd give the sandwich a perfect score.  The side pickles were a nice touch and even had a little kick to them.  I went with the Drunken Lobster Bisque as my side.  It was good, but I don't think it was on par with how good the sandwich was.

Overall a really good experience and I would recommend this restaurant.  I'll be back again for sure.

data.title: Pig out
data.text: I was impressed with the overall experience.  It has a different look because of the location, it is inside another building with cafeteria tables.  Don't let that deter you, the food was great.  In my group we had a chopped chicken salad, meatloaf sandwich and a culture club sandwich.  All very good, I will be back.

data.title: Nice staff, slightly above average food
data.text: The pork sandwich was a little fatty-chewy, and the lobster bisque was way too creamy and salty, but edible. The decor is tragic. They're not even trying.  The staff was great, but they have little to work with.  Great prices.

owner_response.author: Joan I, Owner at The Pickle and the Pig, responded to this review
owner_response.text:
Johnny,
Thank you for your positive criticism on both the pulled pork and the lobster bisque. Given that we are a from scratch kitchen it means that our chef has opportunity to house-brine our pulled pork rather than use a frozen product that tends to be too dry for our clients to enjoy. I assure you that we will take care from this point forward to be aware of, and avoid any fatty-chewy content. As for the Drunken Lobster Bisque, please remember that this is a brandied cream based bisque. If you're not a creamy fan, we encourage you to venture into one of our non cream based options- the Soup Du Jour is almost always a great option for you! 

As I assume you noticed we are located inside of The Legacy Event Center. Our partnership with The Legacy and the YWCA means that we are literally a "pop up restaurant" that tears down daily to allow events to go on in the space. With that- you are correct sir, we are indeed limited in our décor options by design for our staffs sake to simplify their (as you can imagine) rigorous closing duties. However we feel very blessed to have the opportunity to offer unique gourmet sandwich shop in the heart of downtown Lubbock. 
Thank you again for joining us, and taking the time to write on our behalf!
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Sandwiches on homemade bread!!!!
data.text:
Husband and I ate here not too long after they opened, on a Friday. They were packed. His meatball sandwich was really good with a refreshingly different carrot marinara--and the meatballs were stuffed with cheese--and my vegetarian sandwich (can't remember the name) was a LOT of food. We split a side of green chile mac-n-cheese. So good! All the bread is homemade and very tasty. The jalapeno cheese hoagie is covered in cheddar and jalapenos. Waffle chips are different. It's community-style seating, which is fun for Lubbock. 

Great addition to downtown lunch dining.
